Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2014 03:33PM Springlakegirl wrote: Thanks everyone for your input!  My mets in my bones were just in two places in my spine and one in my pelvis.  Now there is no evidence of disease.  I did two half marathons last summer, but right after that was when I got my 3 stress fractures.  I took a few months off and am slowly getting back into it. I won't give up on running that easily!  (I'm a rebel like that!)  ;) It helps me so much in so many ways.  But I know I need to do it carefully and mostly on my treadmill.  Today I just walked because my femurs were sore from running on Tuesday.  I should be able to run again by Saturday.  I probably need to do shorter races too, like 10ks or shorter.  That's fine by me as long as I can still run!  :)

Posts.Title: what a mess chris1959 AmyQ

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2014 01:17AM Springlakegirl wrote: I hated my port!!!  It hurt a lot of times, and totally stuck out really far right where my little girl liked to snuggle up!  She often hurt her head when she suddenly got tired and dropped her head down right there. It hurt me too!!  I also felt like such a patient with that thing in. It was good for chemo, but the second I was done, (and knew I was NED) I had it removed, . . . no regrets! My doctor took a little convincing, but I was determined, and I think she knew it was mentally bad for me to keep  it. If I ever need it again, I will get it, but I hope I will never need it again, and I hope you will never need yours!! Good luck with your decision!!
Posts.Title: Port removal for stage 4 ladies??? Iwillwinthisbattle Nel

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2014 12:33PM Springlakegirl wrote: Divine, I think you are probably right.  I like to be in the driver's seat with my treatment and figure out what I think is best after researching and talking to others about their experiences, looking up studies, etc.., THEN talk to my doctor about it.  I honestly don't love my oncologist right now.  I didn't go to her for all my treatment, but once I got into remission I switched to her because she is close and convenient, and I'm not sick.  If I ever needed major treatment again, I would make the extra drive to go to my previous oncologist.  That being said, I think I will probably talk to her about doing Zometa every 3 months now that I have already done it at every 4 weeks for over two years now.  I am hopeful that will reduce the aching in my bones and allow me to run a little more, while also giving me what I need to keep the cancer out of my bones!  Thanks again for the input!!
Posts.Title: How often should I take Zometa? Springlakegirl Springlakegirl

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2014 06:46PM Springlakegirl wrote: petjunkie, yes, surface matters!  I think you definitely have the idea.  Running out on the road is definitely hard on my bones and I feel it afterward for several day.  Running on the treadmill is much gentler.  And walking on an incline is gentler still.  I highly recommend exercise if at all possible during treatment.  I was able to run or walk much of the time during chemo, radiation, and several surgeries, but some of the time it was a super slow walk.  And of course, some of the time I was hospitalized or couldn't even get out of bed.  Once I got so neurotic in a hospital that I started doing a bunch of laps walking around a circle attached to my pole thingy!  ;)  For me, I HAVE to exercise or I don't feel as good emotionally.  Everyone has their thing that helps I guess!!  I think this whole running thing is going to take some strategic planning, but my goal is to be able to occasionally run outside and occasionally do some road races.  It's just part of who I am!

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2014 04:57PM Springlakegirl wrote: Chickadee, Thank you!  That is helpful.  I guess since I am otherwise feeling great, I want everything to be normal again.  I AM super grateful to be able to exercise at all, but running is my passion, and I want to be able to do it on some level.  I think treadmill running a couple of times a week may possibly work.  I was running outside about 4 times a week when I got my fractures.  I love running outside, but may need to do that once every couple of weeks or something so that I won't get fractures.  i know Zometa or Xgeva is important, I just wonder how frequently most people take it?  How frequently do you take it?
Posts.Title: How often should I take Zometa? Springlakegirl Springlakegirl

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2014 05:54PM Springlakegirl wrote: So sorry you are finding yourself here!  I was diagnosed with Stage 4 BC at age 37 (in 2011), with 2 bone mets on my spine, and one on my hip.  Nothing else.  Our plan of attack was definitely on the aggressive end, because we felt like it was "minimal" metastatic breast cancer, and therefore, we had hope for a cure.  After surgery, chemo, and radiation, I had a complete hysterectomy/oopherectomy.  It could have been done before all of that, but that's just how we did it.  Yes, it was instant menopause, but I had been going through some hot flashes during chemo anyway because that can sometimes kinda kill your ovaries anyway. I didn't have any periods after my first round of chemo.  So . . . the effects of instant menopause was not that bad for me.  I was expecting worse.  I take Anastrozole each day (which is an aromatase inhibitor), to take care of the remaining estrogen in my body. After a lot of research and speaking with several doctors, getting a hysterectomy/oopherectomy seemed like the best way to deal with estrogen when you are pre-menopausal.   Your case seems similar to mine, and I want you to know that I have been in a full remission (totally clear PET scans) for almost 2 years now.  I believe we may have gotten it all, but only time will tell, of course.  If you want to read my story, please feel free.  My website is deniseneish.com  and you can just go to the journal tab and read from the beginning if you would like.  I made my site so that people like you would be able to find some success stories when you receive such a scary diagnosis.  Please read it if you feel it would help you.   There are many other women on this site who have positive stories to share as well.  Some have been NED for many years, and some still have cancer, but have been able to successfully hold it at bay for a long time.  I am praying that you will be comforted during this difficult time.  You aren't alone, and we are all here for you!!

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2014 05:47AM Springlakegirl wrote: I love the title of this thread, and I totally agree!!!  Even fighting for another month or two can sometimes make a very important difference in your family, or the time you have with children.  I was thinking, for example, that my youngest, who just turned 4, would not have remembered me if I had lost my initial battle with cancer.  She already can't remember me being bald, and it wasn't that long ago!! But even a few months could have made the difference in whether she even was able to have a memory of her mother or not, and I think that is important!!  We have enough to battle without inconsiderate people voicing their opinions where it is not wanted!!!  Thanks for your post! deniseneish.com
Posts.Title: Bill Keller is a Cotton-Headed Ninny Muggins EnglishMajor EnglishMajor

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2014 03:22AM Springlakegirl wrote: Divine, You nailed it exactly!  Diet and exercise are important, and something we can all do.  Mental and spiritual stability is definitely important too.  But scientists have tested so many treatments in labs for the very most effective ways to kill cancer, and that's what good doctors recommend for their patients.  I certainly hope Dr. Oz doesn't advocate for any alternative methods INSTEAD of chemo, radiation, Herceptin, Tamoxefin, etc.. (traditional proven approaches).  If he does, he may be causing some women harm by convincing them that they don't need proper treatment.  (He may sort of be trying to indicate that Tamoxefin is not traditional, but it is definitely a powerful first line of treatment for many).  I do, however appreciate the idea that we can benefit from learning and practicing better diets, etc..  Thanks for sharing your positive story Janice, and I'm happy that Tamoxefin is working well for you.  Many women use that as a first approach and it can be very effective.  Hopefully you are done with cancer forever, but if not, there are many chemo drugs or other drugs or treatments out there that have been shown time and time again to have great outcomes for many women.   deniseneish.com

Posts.Content: May 16, 2014 01:13PM Springlakegirl wrote: I'm trying to be really good with my eating too.  I'm avoiding sugar, but not to an extreme measure, because everything has sugar in it, so it makes my life too difficult to be a Nazi about it.  But I avoid all obvious sugar, and I eat whole wheat grains and lots of fruits and veggies.  Overall, when I am being really good about it, I love it!  It makes me feel so much better!  It's definitely worth it.  I have been giving myself Sundays off so that I can make cookies with my kids, etc.  But I find that even on Sundays I don't like to overdo it because my body isn't used to a lot of sweets. I'm working on this along with you!  You can do it if I can!!  ;) deniseneish.com

Posts.Title: Radio interview Springlakegirl Bluemnm

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2014 06:16PM Springlakegirl wrote: Divine, Haha! Yes, good description of Abby Bonell's voice! I agree! And thanks to all of you who said I didn't sound like a kid. "My story" was definitely lacking a lot of the details, but it just went by way too fast for me to really share it all. I think whenever it is your own story, you could really go on about it for a long time, but that wasn't necessarily the goal. ;)  Since "my story" is different than all of yours, I feel the need to let doctors know that they should give more hope to many mbc patients, and I don't want newly diagnosed women to think they need to just lay down and let it take them.  I didn't like the little description that the news station wrote under my podcast on their site though. It basically said that I said cancer patients could beat it if they are "willing to fight". That is not what I said at all. I have always maintained that each case is unique, and each woman should do what she feels is right in her specific situation.  When I feel it's my time to go, I will admire those who have gone before me with grace and dignity, and I will try to remember their courageous examples to me. It's not always time to fight, but my message was more for those who are trying to win a battle. Hopefully that message came through as well. If not, I can't worry too much about it, because it's over, and I did my best.

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2014 05:01AM Springlakegirl wrote: Thanks for all the insights ladies! I really do appreciate hearing what you all think and how you feel about your approach to treatment, etc.. I am more comfortable with the idea of treating this more chronically than I was before. And even though I said that I had a "change in thinking", it wasn't really a drastic change. I have always been cautiously hopeful, but not unrealistically so, . . . I don't think. My hope was based on much more than just the small percentage that are cured for no apparent reason. My hope was always more along the lines of categorizing myself as an "oligomet", which statistically does leave reasonable hope for a cure in my mind. And even now, I do think it's possible that there will be treatments down the road that could do the trick. But if there is just a line up of drugs that can keep me feeling decent for many years while I raise my kids, that is acceptable too. And I think I needed to hear Dr. Valero's "pep talk". He put a good perspective on it for me. Hearing all the wisdom each of you has to share is helpful too.  As for diet, I think it can be quite helpful to be pretty thoughtful about what we take into our bodies. It may not cure cancer, but it can sure help us to feel better each day, and with all the treatment our poor bodies are dealing with, I'll take any advantage I can get! I'm not extreme, and I will indulge once in a while, but mostly I feel better mentally and physically if I'm pretty strict with my diet. But everyone has to do what feels right for them. And sometimes we all need something that just makes us happy in that moment! :) Thanks again for your thoughtfulness all of you! Heidihill, stories like yours are so hopeful! I hope you will continue NED for many more years to come! Ex, you too! Brandall, thank you for sharing your experience with your trial. I hope it will continue to work well for you, and I am very hopeful about starting mine too. Musiclover, I think it's so interesting that some have done so well with such minimal treatment, and change in diet. All of this stuff gives me hope, and I think it's great to share with each other. You all are doing your best to handle things well, and I commend each of you, whatever your personal style may be!

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2014 07:22PM Springlakegirl wrote: TheDivineMR, Thank you for your kind words.  I am so grateful too!  Currently I take Anastrazole every morning, and I get Zometa intravenously every 8 weeks.  I was getting it every 4 weeks, but I recently have had a few stress fractures which I totally attribute to the Zometa (in combination with running).  I am still trying to figure out what I need to do about Zometa because my femurs ache most of the time and I am worried about the effect of Zometa on my bones.  BUT, I don't want to be foolish either, and I know that for bone mets, Zometa has been shown to reduce the likelihood of recurrence.  That is all I am doing right now.  I will continue to go in every 6 months for PET scans for awhile, and I try to eat healthy and exercise, but that's it. What is your situation right now?

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2014 03:12PM Springlakegirl wrote: JHeart,  I'm glad you felt comfortable posting here.  I'm sorry you were hurt, and I understand why!  I remember about 3 months after my diagnosis (we had just moved) and my father-in-law came over and asked if we had been vandalized!  He was just joking, but he knew how hard things had been for us for a few months.  Our lives were turned completely upside down, and decorating our new house or getting everything perfectly placed was not our top priority!   My suggestion would be to just talk to this friend.  Usually communication is the best idea.  Think about what you want to say beforehand so that you don't feel too emotional when you speak with her.  I think it is easy to feel too emotional, or possibly even too easily offended, when you have so much worry and stress in your life.  Under normal circumstances her comments might have been easier to blow off, but right now it may feel more hurtful.  I hope you will communicate your feelings with her, and I am hoping that will rectify the situation.  If not, definitely ask for someone else to be sent, because you don't want to feel humiliated when what you really need is non-judgmental help!  Good luck!! deniseneish.com

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2014 06:51PM Springlakegirl wrote: Thanks for all your comments!  I think that all of you who feel you might somewhat fit into this category definitely have reason to hope!!   Kandy, I know that radiation is more effective than chemo at killing cancer, and so that makes sense.  I guess the systemic treatment on top of that is just an effort to cover all the bases, but if those are the only spots, then that could definitely be enough.  I'm so happy you are doing well! LuAnnh, many good points in your comments! Heidihill, Thank you for sharing your article.  It really is promising!  I think the reason they never give stats for overall survival rates it just because it's hard to calculate.  They would need to wait until all those subjects died cancer-free of something else before they could count them.  But I think it only makes sense that if the numbers are way better for a certain subcategory of MBC patients who treat it a certain way, then the overall survival rates must be higher too. And thank you JillThut for your comment.  I think that's very true.  I have noticed that the comments on this board are almost always so supportive and kind-hearted that I think the women who post here are understanding enough to see some posts that might not be right for them, and just move on without feeling hurt.  That's my hope anyway!   NewportCB, I'm so sorry that you have to be searching for answers right now.  I am sorry for your diagnosis, and I truly wish you the best!  I made a personal website sharing my story and some personal thoughts on dealing with stage 4 breast cancer.  Please feel free to peruse it if it seems like something that would help right now.  You are exactly who I made it for!  The first part of my journal is long and hard to get through because I had so much on my mind as I wrote, but it gets better as it goes along because there is a happy ending!!  :)  I'm still here and NED, and hope to be that way for a long long time!!  Love and hugs to you and your husband!!  This is my site:  deniseneish.com Ladies, I hope you will keep posting your positive stories and more optimistic studies that you find.  The mind is powerful, and hope is not misplaced if there are some valid reasons for it!!  Thank you so much for sharing!!

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2014 08:01AM Springlakegirl wrote: I'm sure I am guilty of using terminology that could hurt someone out there who is dealing with this devastating disease.  I have words that are turn-offs for me too, but I won't list them right now.  In general, though, I don't like it when people tell me I'm "incurable".  That's the word that doesn't sit well with me.  Who has the right to tell me that I won't be one of the few fortunate ones who "wins this fight"?!  Okay, I get saucy when I'm healthy, like I am right now, so hopefully I won't offend anyone who hates those words!  ;)   Bestbird, I hope you don't mind if I share a poem I wrote right when I was in the thick of treatment.  I almost lost my life during chemo and was hospitalized for about a month, away from my hubby and four small children.  When I got home and recovered for a few weeks, before starting chemo again, I went out on a little walk/run on a beautiful day.  It was the first time I had the energy to do that in a long time, and I came home inspired to write a poem.  (I don't normally write poetry).  I'm not saying it's a great poem or anything, but it just flowed out of me and was exactly what I had been feeling, and I felt fully satisfied with it when I was done.  A lot of analogy in it, but I think many of you could relate.  I will share it for those of you interested in reading: Mother of Four Battling Metastatic Breast Cancer: I stepped out into the world one day to go for a run. I was eager to try out my brand new running shoes. The sky was brilliant as the sun rose over the mountains. I breathed in the fresh crisp air as I laced on my shoes. I was ready for this run! It was hard to contain my energy and strength as I bounded out onto the pavement. I smiled at the little flowers I saw blooming on the side of the hill. It was almost effortless to glide forward at a nimble pace. Sometimes I accelerated without even noticing. Other times I stopped and dawdled at the side of the road. Frequently there were others around me. We ran together for a while and compared running shoes. We gleefully splashed through puddles, and trudged up steep hills together. We held our arms up in the air as we recklessly sprinted down the hills and into the valleys. Soon one was running beside me. He made my heart pound deeper. My steps grew in rhythm with his. We turned onto a new path together. It felt familiar. It was our own. Our new path was narrower. It was a lovely winding path with playful white flowers freckled along the side. We splashed in the cool mountain stream that bordered our path. We climbed a tree to get a better view and chartered our course. Our shoes were slightly worn now, but we had taken good care of them, and knew that we could run many more miles on them. We loved our new path. We vowed to run on it together forever. We decided to share our path with four new runners. We were so excited to show them everything. We laughed as they marveled at their new shoes. We taught them to lace up their shoes, stretch, and run, run, RUN!!!!! If they fell, we picked them up and brushed the dirt from their knees. “Your wound will heal” we said, “It is not so bad. Now get back up and run!“ It was hard to keep up with them sometimes! But other times they lay peacefully in our arms as we reverently watched them sleep. They were amazing. We held hands and ran slower so that we could all stay together. A steady pace forward and side by side was our goal. The radiant sun was still high in the sky. Suddenly a thorn shot through my shoe and tore deeply into my foot. I was stunned at first and stumbled. I could not get the bleeding to stop. I fell and cried. The wound was too deep to heal, I was told. I could see the wound, but I couldn’t feel the pain. Someone cries beside me. He takes my hand again. We are wounded together. We are lost from our course. How could we lose our beautiful path? This was not what we planned. We tell our little runners that it will be okay. It will heal. Then we continue to run on our new path as the sun begins to hide behind the mountain. We quicken our pace to beat the setting sun. We hold each other’s hands. Our little runners can feel our grips tighten. When I am too weak to run, he carries me for a while. I try to smile and I run when I can. Our path gets steeper and darker. I try to move forward on my own, and our hands lose contact briefly. I can feel the pain now. Our little runners cling to us and stumble when we do. We reach out to find one another again and turn the corner. The path is unfamiliar ahead. If we cannot get back onto our beautiful path, can we make this one ours? We decide to recharter our course. First we must stop and remove the thorn, we decide. It will hurt, but it must come out if there is any chance for it to heal. We let ourselves believe that it can heal. We cannot remove my shoe completely or I will have to go home right away. We know that we will both end our run at home, but we want to enjoy the path together as long as we can. We try to remove all of the thorn. We don’t want to leave any part behind. I sob with pain as it being removed. Sometimes I stop and take a deep breath. “We have to continue“, I say. My will to be rid of the thorn is increasing. I want to believe that my shoe can be as good as new. Our little ones play alongside the path, unaware of the thorn. I want to watch them grow into strong runners. There is so much for me to teach them before we go on separate paths. They come over to us when they see the clouds darkening, and we tickle them and tell them to go play by the stream for a while. This will just take a moment longer. We struggle to get rid of the thorn. Feeling weak, we cry out to God. “Please heal this wound!!” Others encircle us and lift me to my feet. “If you do your best to repair your shoe, I will take care of your foot” comes the answer. We summon all our strength and pull as hard as we can on the thorn. It comes out but leaves a wound in my foot and a hole in the shoe. We ask others for help to repair the shoe. We want to do the very best job we can so that the shoe will last a long time. We have to use what is around us to repair it. The repair job seems solid, but the shoe will never be completely the same. I look at all who have gathered around me on our path. They are telling me that it will be okay. They encourage me to keep running. I don’t like this path as much as the one I started on, but I am not alone like I was at the beginning of my run. I decide that my foot needs to be stronger if my shoe is weakened. I did not start this run only to go home early. I will run better than I have ever run before! I take his hand again with renewed energy. I can feel my foot healing already. We take our four little runners and begin again. The path takes us around another corner, and the sun is still shining. We only thought the sun was setting because of our place on the path. My shoe is working well, but we know that all of our shoes will wear out eventually. Then we will go to our beautiful home and rejoice at the new shoes that await us there that will never wear out. But in the meantime, we look around and notice that the path is much more interesting than we thought. The shadows only make the sunlit parts look brighter. There is still a long way to go on the path before we reach our home. We will never be the same as we were before the thorn. In many ways we are stronger. We are more aware that our run cannot last forever, but we are not afraid. We vow to run our best, to splash in the stream, to raise our hands in the air and run recklessly down the hills, to lift those we see who have fallen on the path, to tickle our little runners, to teach them all we know, and to hold hands all the way home.    Thanks for reading :) deniseneish.com

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2014 11:54AM Springlakegirl wrote: Okay, first of all, I love your screen name!  That is the kind of attitude that you need!!  I think attitude is crucial when diagnosed with stage 4.  I was diagnosed with stage 4 breast cancer in April 2011 at age 37.  The cancer had spread to my spine and pelvis.  From the beginning, I was repeatedly told that I was "incurable".  To be honest, that is not a fully accurate label for those diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer.  There are 1-3% who ARE cured.  And there are many who live a long time with the cancer.  I know doctors feel the responsibility to give us the hard facts, but they are skipping the part about their being some hope for full recovery out there.  I believe in that hope, and I believe I may be in that category.  Why not me?  Why not you?  I have been in full remission for the last year and a half.  I know the odds of it coming back are very real, but I choose to assume the best and hope for the best.  I just made a website to share my experience with those who have been given that same prognosis.  my website is deniseneish.com if you are interested in reading my story.  For some reason my blood does not have the tumor markers in it.  Some people don't have that for some reason.  So I have always had to rely on PET scans, but I did have a questionable lymph node in my last scan, and we decided to remove it from my neck.  After the surgery it was biopsied and was totally clean.  No cancer.  I really want all of you out there who are in that wonderful place of NED to know that there are survivors of stage 4 breast cancer out there, and to hope for the best while living your lives to the fullest!  Much love and best wishes to all of you.
Posts.Title: Are all NEDs created equal?? Iwillwinthisbattle Bestbird

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2014 02:07PM Springlakegirl wrote: TheDivineMrsM, Thank you!!  I just needed to have a place to put down some of my thoughts and a website was what worked for me.  The video was from a local race to raise money for cancer patients and my nurses recommended me to the PR guy, so I got to have a nice little video to keep from that.   I don't blame you at all for keeping your stage four diagnosis to yourself.  Each case is so individual!  You definitely need family support though, and it sounds like you have that at least.  It is nice to connect with some people like you on this site who have dealt with similar issues.  Yes, it was crazy dealing with chemo and hospitalization while my kids were so little!  I have never felt more needed in my life than I did during that time, and I was absolutely useless for a while.  My oldest niece (age 20 at the time) was able to move in with us for a few months when I was really sick, and that saved us!  That and some other family members and great friends.  We were very supported, and we definitely needed it.  I feel so sorry for those who don't have the kind of support around them that they need!  Best to you and your family!!
Posts.Title: Are all NEDs created equal?? Iwillwinthisbattle Bestbird

Posts.Title: Hope for those wanting to get on Palbociclib (Ibrance) Springlakegirl Moderators

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2015 03:25PM Springlakegirl wrote: Bestbird, That's a good question! I was in remission for 2 years on Anastrozole, then it failed me in July 2014, and I had a recurrence in my right iliac bone. At that time, we explored all the options out there, and with my oncologist, came to the conclusion that it would be great if I could get on a trial of Palbociclib (or another CDK inhibitor). I then went to MD Anderson in Houston for a second opinion, and without telling him what my oncologist said, he recommended the exact same thing. At that time I really came to feel at peace with that decision for my next treatment, but quickly found out it was harder to get on than I realized. I decided to stick with my decision to get on Palbociclib, but didn't want to go untreated for too long, and decided to take Tamoxifen in the interim. When Pfizer started the expanded access program last October, I met all the requirements to get into that trial, but my hospital did not have the trial, and so they began the process of getting approved for it. According to my doctor it was the longest process, with the most hoops to jump through, that she has ever experienced, and they were still in the process of getting approved for the trial when Pfizer announced that Palbociclib was FDA approved. They would not open any new sites for the expanded access program, yet they redefined the eligibility for Palbociclib as those who had not been on any prior endocrine therapy. This seemingly excluded me. I am a person who does a lot of research, thinking, and praying about my treatment, and then after that, I really rely on my gut feeling. So, after a recent PET scan which showed that the Tamoxifen seems to be keeping my cancer stable, I could definitely continue with Tamoxefin, but I just don't want to! That's the long answer to your short question! On paper, continuing on Tamoxifen is a reasonable option, but it's not what I feel right about, and not what I want to do. I only have one little spot of cancer right now, and I want to be on the most effective treatment that will hopefully get me back to NED, or at least keep me stable, for many years to come, and I think (and hope) Palbociclib is what will do that for me. I was getting discouraged that my "gut feeling" was off because Palbo didn't seem to be available to me, but now I feel much more comfortable, and at peace, that I will be able to follow the treatment I feel best about.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2014 04:11PM - edited Jan 28, 2014 04:42PM by Springlakegirl Thanks Bon!  Yes, I noticed the date on that study too.  I wasn't focusing so much on what exact treatments they were using in the study, just the fact that they were actually studying Metastatic Breast Cancer patients over an extended period of time was what caught my eye.  I haven't really seen another study quite as thorough as that.  And even though it is older, it was sooooo much more hopeful than what my doctor told me!!  (I related a lot to the specific women they were studying.  My mets were to bone only and I just had 3 spots.)  Anyway, this was a really well-done study, and I'd like to see more current information on the same topic if anyone has something they have found.  Please share!! :) deniseneish.com

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2014 11:19PM Springlakegirl wrote: Okay ladies, Here is a much more current study.  I will put the link on here.  The findings on this one are even better than the previous study I posted.  The conclusion at the end says this: Conclusion:  The present analyses clearly indicate that OMBC is a distinct subgroup with long-term prognosis superior to MBC, with reasonable provability for clinical cure. Further prospective studies to better characterize OMBC are warranted to improve prognosis in MBC. OMBC for those of you who don't know is "oligomets metastatic breast cancer", in other words, only one spot where the cancer has metastasized.  I would assume results would be similar for those with just a few spots, especially if those spots were locally treated as well as systemically treated.   http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22532161 Some of the stats in this article are so much more promising than what many of our oncologists told us to begin with, and that is why many women under-treat metastatic breast cancer, because they are given the impression that their is no hope at all for them.  I think that some women would choose more aggressive treatment if they fit into certain criteria, and if they knew that their odds for long-term survival, or even cure, were a lot higher than the whole big category of 'Stage 4 breast cancer'.   I mean, we talk about doctors being straight with us, but that doesn't always mean that they need to be more negative about our odds for survival.  Sometimes that means they need to be more optimistic.  Especially if they are saying you are "incurable" like they said to me.  I didn't buy it, and I'm glad I didn't and that I treated it aggressively, because in my particular case, I had a real chance to knock it down, and I'm hoping that's what we did!   I just want other women in similar situations to know that they may have every reason to insist on aggressive treatment if that feels right for them.  I feel passionately about it, and hope that more research and effort goes into cure for metastatic breast cancer so that the odds will continue to improve!!  I love all you ladies who are struggling with this disease, and I want all the information to be shared so that everyone can make their best decisions.  Sometimes there is really no reason to "accept" something as inevitable if you think you have a chance to kick it's a$$!!!  ;)   (I continue to worry about posting these types of messages if it is discouraging for those who do not fit into this category.  Please accept my apologies if I offended anyone, but I do feel it's an important topic for some of us.) deniseneish.com

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2015 01:34PM Springlakegirl wrote: She should definitely let her oncologist know. When I was in chemo and got a little sick, and had a fever, I didn't know how serious it was, but I went downhill pretty fast because my body just couldn't fight it off. I got mouth sores, couldn't eat, and when my nurse found out I had a fever she admitted me to the hospital. I ended up in the hospital on and off for a few weeks before they got the infections in my body under control. It seems strange, but when you are in chemo, your body just doesn't have much of an ability to fight off infection. I had fevers off and on for over a week before I was admitted to the hospital, and my body was in pretty bad shape by the time I got in there. The sooner she can get on the correct antibiotics, the sooner she will be able to fight off the infections. It may not be too bad if she gets it taken care of quickly. I just had to voice my opinion on this matter though, in case it makes a difference in her going in. It's not okay to have a fever when you are in chemo. All my best to your mom!
